review_title: Great place to work as a student
pros: Access to great things to learn and grow.
cons: Nothing that i can think.

pros: You get paid and left alone as long as the students are happy
cons: I never hear anything. I'm proud that I'm in the top 10% in terms of student feedback but I'm never offered any opportunities to teach other courses. I feel sometimes as if I'm kept in a box and brought out to teach every so often. The Academic Portfolio Administrators seem to assign courses based on who they like rather than using any logical criteria. I never hear ANYTHING from the college and I've been teaching there for almost 7 years. Also, I've just started teaching at Mohawk and my hourly rate is 75% higher for a similar course (although my class size is 50% bigger). However, Mohawk is smaller and seems more "personal" - we'll see. If you interview there - ask about opportunities to grow. Also - their Centre for Teaching & Learning is too focused on theoretical teaching tools and techniques - as well as DEI. I'm not saying that's unimportant - it's that there are so many practical things to do to make the courses more consistent and have practical value to the students. Many of the CTL staff them have NO teaching experience. It's very frustrating.

job_title: Assistant to the Director in Oakville, ON
pros:
Amazing benefits - a lot of vacation days, 2nd best pension plan in Ontario, work hours flexibility, hybrid work (can work from home), lots of PD opportunities, health, and dental benefits, free course, etc.
Amazing people - everyone is very passionate about what they do, supportive, and hardworking.
What you do makes a positive impact on students' lives, country, and the world through academics, research, and the Sustainable Development Goals framework.
Great work atmosphere - you are treated with respect, understanding, and compassion. Very few workplaces can boast this.
Overall, the best place I have ever worked. The cons are worth it!
cons:
The workload is very heavy, and resources are few, so you have to work overtime on regular basis. There is no compensation for overtime. 
Career growth is limited and very slow. To move up you will either have to wait for 8-10 years or get a job in another post-secondary institution.
Non-competitive salaries.
No compensation for outstanding performance. There are no bonuses and your raise does not depend on your performance. 
The support staff has fewer benefits than the admin staff.

review_title: Be careful of the PT instructor trap
pros: I believe the school's educational facilities and programs are excellent and offer a strong balance between real-world skills and training and academics. Individuals within departments (both administrative and faculty) can be very good to work with.
cons: As a PT instructor, there is very little support when it comes to on-boarding. You're often thrown into a new course and it's incumbent on you to track down former teachers (sometimes PT themselves) and try to obtain their course material. There is a very wide disparity between what full-time faculty are paid and the support you receive and what you earn as a PT or sessional instructor. Expect to work at least an additional 2-3 hours per hour spent in the classroom (preparation, marking, meeting with students, etc.). During end-of-semester grading it's more like 4-5 hours per in-class hour. There are few full-time faculty positions available. None of this is specifically Sheridan's fault: it's the nature of these big institutions relying on PT instruction which I've come to feel is exploitative.

pros: Great place to work if you can get in with connections.
cons: Absolutely rife with nepotism. A complete outsider does not stand a chance.

pros: very creative community, incredibly talented students and faculty,  in the arts in particular.  some good initiatives to break into higher level polytechnic/university status, which would free up money (if available - odds on this are low)...generally cordial relations with management, with exceptions.
cons: some levels of administration have serious issues with competency - very basic things can be screwed up routinely with little accountability.  Organization is increasingly top-heavy, adding layers that really don't help front-line delivery much.  Part time faculty are grossly underpaid with little flexibility in enhancing contracts.

pros: Lots of great people to work with, the students can be a lot of fun.  Tons of diversity.
cons: No room to grow, very poor management.  Management are more worried about covering their behinds than they are about managing the people they are responsible for.  I experienced a ton of issues -- including both mental and physical harassment -- that management just didn't take seriously or address adequately.  Being good at your job doesn't count for much here, lots of people with seniority are happy to do nothing and management are terrified to actually address these kinds of issues.  The union that was supposed to have my back fit the same description as the management.

pros: Lots of great staff and faculty, talented in their fields, that are passionate about higher education.
cons: Lots of people in leadership roles that are entrenched in outmoded vision and management models.  People with passion and creativity are often stifled, despite the organization's mantra ("get creative").  Tendency of hiring people into leadership roles on the basis of prior relationships rather than competency (often from much smaller environments), that are particularly self-serving and barely capable of being managers as opposed to leaders.  This has created toxic environments in several areas of the College, which is causing the most valuable employees to flee (or even be let go, where they threaten the status quo).

pros: It’s like being a part of a tight, close-knit family. Everyone helps one another, looks out for each other, share workloads without fear of being overshadowed or that credit will not be given where it’s due, and they drive you to succeed without expecting anything in return. The students are the team’s priority, and they do everything they can to prevent issues that may arise, and resolve them when they do come up.
cons: There are cons? I didn’t see any in that area I worked in.

Associate Deans caught between a rock and a hard place. Emphasis on money received not on quality provided.
